titleStmt.title: From fish physiology to ecosystems management: Keys for moving through biological levels of organization in detecting environmental changes and anticipate their consequences

analytic.title: From fish physiology to ecosystems management: Keys for moving through biological levels of organization in detecting environmental changes and anticipate their consequences

biblStruct.note: Received 18 November 2017; Received in revised form 4 March 2018; Accepted 8 March 2018

textClass.keywords: Conservation Biological organization levels Physiology Epigenetic Dynamic energy budget Energy allocation rules Life story strategies Bioindicators Scaling indicators

div.p: Tackling environmental problems not only requires the detection of harmful agents or the drivers that induce changes in ecosystems and their effects, but also knowledge of their action mechanisms and the processes involved in order to design solutions, recover the damaged systems and, above all, prevent any deterioration before it occurs. In recent years conservation physiology has been proposed as a discipline that could play an important role in this context. However, the main problem in generalizing physiological indicators in order to assess ecological status is the leap in scale from the internal physiology of an individual to its relevance for ecosystem functioning. In this paper, we propose that the study of the physiological bases and epigenetic mechanisms that determine the allocation of energy resources, in the context of Dynamic Energy Budget theory, can be the hinge that allows us to pass from the physiology of the individual to the scale of population dynamics, the structure of populations and ecosystems. This proposal is based on the strong relationship shown by the parameters of the life story of individuals, such as body growth rate, maximum size, life expectancy or generation time, with the parameters that determine population growth and the ecological strategies of the species. There is growing evidence that the relationship between these parameters is not completely fixed and does not only respond to evolutionary scales, but may be flexible within certain limits throughout ontogeny and the life of individuals, producing consequences in populations in response to environmental conditions, environmental stress and, in the case of fish, the effects of fishing. Lay summary: Biological index to detect environmental impacts can be applied from cell to ecosystem scale. However, at lower levels, although they give important information on the mechanisms involved it is difficult to infer the real consequences of the detected changes on the ecosystems. The review of the regularities existing in ecological guilds relationships of fishes suggests that the study of the physiological and epigenetic bases that determine the allocation of energy resources in the context of Dynamic Energy Budget theory can be the hinge that allows us to pass from the effects on the physiology of the individual to the scale of population dynamics and ecosystems when modelling the consequences of changes in environmental stress.

div.head: Introduction/context
div.p: Tackling environmental problems requires multidisciplinary efforts. It is not sufficient to detect harmful agents or the drivers that induce changes in ecosystems and their effects. We also need to know how they act on the processes taking place and how to correct any deviation from good functioning through remediation and the management of recovery actions. But above all, we need to anticipate these changes before they occur, modelling connections between drivers, processes and consequences.

After publication of the Water Framework Directive in the European Union (2000), there was a huge increase in the use of classical biological indicators and in the number of new ones proposed to characterize the ecological status of aquatic ecosystems (Salas et al., 2006;Gamito, 2008;Birk et al., 2012). Although most of them focus on species and community structure, the negative effects of human impact and climatic change have consequences for all biological levels of organization (Lloyd, 1991;van der Oost et al., 2003;Sánchez and Porcher, 2009).

In recent years, conservation physiology has focused on conservation problems, applying physiological concepts and knowledge to Fig. 1. a) Effects of environmental stress and pollutants on the different biological organization levels (from cells to ecosystem) and biological and ecological processes involved; b) main approaches, tools and types of bio-indicators that can be used to detect deterioration at the different levels. The research at lower levels allows us to better understand the mechanisms of action on the physiology and function of living things. In contrast, analysis of the upper levels is more relevant for understanding the real impact on the biosphere. AMBI: AZTI Marine Biotic Index; BENTIX: Bentix index (Simboura & Zenetos, 2002); ABC: Abundance Biomass Curve; P/B: Production/Biomass. understand and predict the response of organisms, populations and ecosystems to environmental change and stressors (Cooke et al., 2013). This approach needs to consider spatial, temporal and biological scales and work across the different levels of biological organization (Cooke et al., 2014). While as a discipline it might be considered as new (Lennox and Cooke, 2014), physiological indicators in key organisms have been used to characterize the level of pollution, especially in aquatic ecosystems, for many years (Axiak, 1991).

Fish are particularly good candidates for exploring the links between physiological processes and physiological reactions to environmental stressors and the consequences at both community and ecosystem levels (Horodysky et al., 2015). They constitute a taxonomic group that is widely distributed across all aquatic environments, from fresh waters to deep marine habitats, in transitional and coastal waters, from polluted estuaries to coral reefs. They also show a wide range of trophic levels, from detritus feeders to planktivores, herbivores and top predators, and, in general, they cover a complete spectrum of ecological traits and physiological adaptations.

Despite this, within the Water Framework Directive, fish assemblages are only recognized as an indicator group of ecosystem status in the case of fresh and transitional waters, while they are excluded from coastal waters assessments. However, the use of fish as an indicator of the reserve effect in Marine Protected Areas is widely accepted throughout the world (Halpern, 2003;Claudet et al., 2008Claudet et al., , 2010García-Charton et al., 2008) and some species, like Zebra fish, have become a model for many biochemical and physiological studies with human applications (Makhija and Jagtap, 2014;Vila et al., 2014;Das et al., 2015;Kamstra et al., 2015;Tian and Zhu, 2015). Recently, Marine Strategy Framework Directive includes among its objectives to contribute to the integration of environmental concerns, into other the Common Fisheries Policy. The latter explicitly consider, based on scientific advice, the full closure to fisheries of certain areas, to enable the integrity, structure and functioning of ecosystems in order to safeguard spawning, nursery and feeding grounds and at the same time, MSFD includes, among qualitative descriptors for determining good environmental status, the population parameters of all commercially exploited fish and shellfish indicative of a healthy stock (European Union, 2008). As a consequence, the search for indicators and biomarkers based on or including fish has been reactivated (Östman et al., 2017). These proposals focus on physiological or individual biomarkers (Sánchez and Porcher, 2009;Beyer et al., 2014;Lyons et al., 2017) or on assemblage descriptors (Henriques et al., 2013;Rombouts et al., 2013;Bergström et al., 2016;Modica et al., 2016;Östman et al., 2017) and Ecosystem Based Fisheries Management (EBFM) approaches (Fay et al., 2013), including the descriptors of the trophic web (Tam et al., 2017;Torres et al., 2017;Otto et al., 2018), but they maintain the classic dichotomy between the knowledge of the mechanisms of action versus that of relevance to the ecosystem (Lloyd, 1991;Forbes et al., 2006;Sánchez and Porcher, 2009). In fact, evaluating the ecological relevance of individual level effects is considered one of the major challenges facing ecotoxicologists (Maltby, 1999).

In this paper we discuss the role that fish ecophysiology can play in linking physiological processes at individual level with relevant changes at ecosystem level, and as a tool to design new indicators that permit changes in the crucial phases of deterioration of the ecosystem integrity to be detected. We study the relationships between the different parameters constituting ecological traits in fish obtained from FISHBASE data (Froese and Pauly 2008, http://www.fishbase.org/) and propose that the study of the physiological bases and epigenetic mechanisms that determine the allocation of energy resources, in the context of Dynamic Energy Budget theory, can be the hinge that allows us to model the effects of environmental stress or fishing pressure on the structure and dynamics of populations and ecosystems.

2. Looking for indicators to detect environmental problems, and constraints of the physiological approach Environmental stress and pollutants affect living organisms at all levels of biological organization, from cells to ecosystems (Maltby, 1999) (Fig. 1a), altering the processes that regulate the functioning and dynamics at each level. This implies a cascade of effects that leads from changes in physiology and cellular metabolism to alterations in the growth and behaviour of individuals, in the structure and dynamics of populations and in interspecific relationships and ecosystem structure. In severe situations, these alterations may lead to the illness or death of individuals, the local or total extinction of species, regressions in the ecological succession and even the disappearance of ecosystems (Maltby, 1999).

At genomic level, organisms can face pollution stress regulating gene expression at the point that it can be linked to phenotypic and environmental variation, and gene expression profiles can disclose the signatures of pollutants (Venier et al., 2006, Pujolar et al., 2012. Extreme conditions, involving mortality, can lead to population genetic drifts and, through bottlenecks or genetic selection in isolation, to speciation.

The consequences of, or responses to, stress can be detected at the different levels of biological organization by means of laboratory and mesocosm experiments or by sampling experimental designs in the field, if suitable bioindicators are used (Fig. 1b). For each biological organization level, a high number of bioindicators and biological indices have been proposed in the bibliography (Féral et al., 2003;Gubbay, 2004;ICES, 2008;Pérez-Domínguez et al., 2012;Dondero and Calisi, 2015). However, no single one has demonstrated itself to be applicable in all situations (Salas et al., 2006;ICES, 2008).

At the lowest organization levels, the responses closely reflect the biochemical or physiological mechanisms that explain the effects of physical stress or chemical substances on the health or normal functioning of individuals (Corsi et al., 2003;van der Oost et al., 2003;Porte et al., 2006;Sarkar et al., 2004;Beyer et al., 2014;Dondero and Calisi, 2015;Torres et al., 2008), but at these levels, although there has been some attempt to relate it to higher levels of organization, such as the diversity of parasites (Broeg et al., 1999), we are far from knowing the real consequences that these alterations may have for population, community or ecosystem levels (Lloyd, 1991;Harding, 1992;Galloway and Depledge, 2001;van der Oost et al., 2003;Moore et al., 2004;Forbes et al., 2006). At the other extreme, although at the highest organization levels, the real consequences of any impact on the ecosystem can be detected (Gray, 1982;Rombouts et al., 2013), we may lose sight of the action mechanisms involved, making it difficult to look for alternatives or preventive measures that will minimize any impact (Lloyd, 1991;Harding, 1992;Maltby, 1999;Sánchez and Porcher, 2009).

A large number of diagnostic techniques to detect loss of fitness at organism level are available. These include biochemical, genetic, cytohistological and pathological indicators, behaviour analysis, and many typical physiological measurements based on respiration rates, excretion, O:N ratios, etc. (Axiak, 1991;Sarkar et al., 2004).

However, the use of physiological measures as indicators requires good knowledge of the link between the value of a physiological parameter and the health status of the individual and the effects on higher levels (Moore et al., 2004). Abel (1989) lists more than 40 different physiological or biochemical measurements mentioned in the literature, but suggests that many of them may be reactions to stress in natural situations, like those associated with reproductive periods, rather than real harmful or toxic effects. That is, they can not differentiate natural homeostatic adjustments and regulatory processes (e.g. excitation in reproductive periods, or responses to natural fluctuations in light, salinity or temperature) from malfunctioning and physiological response to human impact.

In the same way, at community level, regulatory mechanisms or homeorhetic controls (sensu Odum, 2000) also exist. Homeorhesis at community and ecosystem level is a laxer regulatory mechanism than homeostasis at individual level, which acts by alternating positive and negative feedbacks, with more pulsing and chaotic behaviour, leading to pulsing balances rather than equilibriums or steady states (Odum and Barret, 2006). These self-regulatory mechanisms may mask the symptoms of stress and prevent detection of the pressures that are occurring in the ecosystem until it is too late. This has been observed particularly in the case of eutrophication throughout top-down control of the trophic web (Scheffer, 1998;Cloern, 2001;Pérez-Ruzafa et al., 2002, 2004Heck and Valentine, 2007;Newell et al., 2007;Lonsdale et al., 2009). Therefore, even though differences between the values measured and those obtained in controls may be statistically significant, they may not necessarily reflect individual damage or have ecological meaning (Krebs, 1999). The differences observed may simply indicate that the organisms have adjusted to the new environmental conditions in a range of natural possibilities, and not necessarily that the changes are harmful to them. In other words, statistical significance does not always have biological consequences. Any physiological or biochemical change measured, or any observed alteration in the behaviour of an organism or the histological appearance of a given tissue, may represent homeostatic or normal responses that do not involve significant energetic costs (Fig. 2). In this context, the problem arises of how we can know the normal range of variation for different species, beyond which real harm to the organism may occur.

The proliferation of indices arising after publication of the Water Framework Directive in 2000 (Salas et al., 2006;Gamito, 2008;Birk et al., 2012) has not solved the old problem of looking for good indicators (Salas et al., 2006), and any new ones proposed still do not satisfy all the requirements. Furthermore, the bibliography is replete with works detecting exceptions, mismatches between different indicators, disagreement with experts' judgement, and continuous recalibrations or new proposals for the most widely used indices (Simboura and Reizopoulou, 2008;Teixeira et al., 2010;Sigovini et al., 2013;Borja et al., 2015;Brauko et al., 2016;Luo et al., 2016;Mulik et al., 2017;Khedhri et al., 2017;Sánchez-Moyano et al., 2017;Berthelsen et al., 2018;Pitacco et al., in press).

Therefore, it seems advisable to use more than one of these bioindicators (Fulton et al., 2005;Rombouts et al., 2013;Modica et al., 2016;Sivadas et al., 2016) and cover different levels of biological organization (Harding, 1992;Pérez-Ruzafa and Marcos, 2015). Moreover, the diagnosis of ecosystem health or ecological quality must be based on the set of indicators chosen, but taking into account that each one should be measured independently, using the corresponding techniques and measurement units, and compared with its own baseline and reference values (Pérez-Ruzafa and Marcos, 2015). All this information must be integrated in the diagnostic process, while retaining the original information and identifying the values of each variable in the context of eco-physiological relationship processes and interpreting them in the context of the environmental changes observed, the characteristics of the habitat and the biogeographical region (Pérez-Ruzafa and Marcos, 2015).

As commented before, one of the main challenges in looking for indicators to prevent environmental deterioration is to know the point at which the measured variable falls outside the normal range of a healthy animal or ecosystem or when the deviation anticipates major changes with consequences for higher organization levels; hence, it is necessary to collect as much information as possible about the physiological and biochemical intervals of healthy organisms that are not exposed to any form of toxic pollution or environmental stress. Most of the indicators currently used, at physiological and at community and ecosystem levels, are useful for detecting changes in region B of Fig. 2. However, we need to find good indicators and understand the processes occurring in regions A and C if significant deterioration or irreparable damage, respectively, is to be anticipated. In both regions, the transition phase can be difficult to anticipate because sudden and dramatic changes can occur in the framework of catastrophe theory sensu Thom (1989) (Pérez-Ruzafa and Marcos, 2015).

div.head: Scope for growth and energy allocation as the hinge between physiological indicators and ecosystem management
div.p: Recently, the need to integrate different observation scales and different levels of biological organization has been recognized as essential for the development of conservation physiology (Cooke et al., 2014). However, while physiological processes are close to low organization levels and are a good tool to understand action mechanisms, they look like too far from anticipate the consequences at ecosystem level. In fact, as commented above, the main problem in the generalization of physiological indicators for assessing the ecological status is the leap in scale from the internal physiology of an individual and its relevance for ecosystem functioning.

The concept of 'oxygen and capacity dependent thermal tolerance' (OCLTT) has been proposed as an integrator of multiple effects, linking various levels of biological organisation, from genome via molecular, cellular, whole organism to ecosystem (Pörtner 2002(Pörtner , 2010. The question arises how to implement these conceptual developments, which firmly rest on an integrative understanding of physiological data, into an ecosystem level understanding (Pörtner, 2012).

However, a good way to overcome such problems at populations level is to assess whether the observed changes affect individuals aerobic scope in the context of Dynamic Energy Budget theory (DEB) (Kooijman, 2000;Sousa et al., 2008), understanding the gene expression regulations and the physiological mechanisms operating in the trade-off between growth and reproduction at individual and population level. DEB theory, suggests that a general model describing the acquisition of energy by an individual organism, and its utilization for growth, reproduction and survival, may have the potential to link processes at different organizational levels, from molecules, to cells, organisms, populations and ecosystems (Nisbet et al., 2000). Recently, Kearney (2012) assessed the potential for integrating DEB theory with Fig. 2. Scheme of the response of an organism or an ecosystem to increasing stress due to extreme environmental conditions or pollutant concentrations (modified from Lloyd, 1972;Pérez-Ruzafa and Marcos, 2015). Main effects involve changes in functional status, from health to different degrees of disability, and physiological impairment. Most of the indicators currently used, both at the physiological and the community and ecosystem level, are able to detect changes in the region B. However, we need to find good indicators and understand the processes in regions A and C, to anticipate significant deterioration or irreparable damage, respectively. In both regions, the phase transition can be difficult to anticipate because sudden and dramatic changes can occur in the framework s of catastrophe theory. biophysical ecology to make first-principles estimates of the energy budget, life-history patterns and geographic range limits of a terrestrial ectotherm and to infer the impact of changing environments on the distribution and abundance of organisms. However, their complexity can be an obstacle to be used by both fish physiologists and fisheries scientists (Horodysky et al., 2015).

DEB theory is based on physical principles and on the κ-rule model developed by Kooijman (1986Kooijman ( , 1993Kooijman ( , 2000Kooijman ( , 2010. Growth ceases when a fixed fraction κ of the available energy just meets somatic maintenance demands (Nisbet et al., 2000). Therefore, it is assumed that in the standard DEB model (i.e. the simplest DEB model), the growth rate of an organism in constant conditions decreases linearly with size as the result of the differences between anabolic processes and catabolic processes. However, we suggest that to scale physiological processes to ecological consequences more research is needed to understand the epigenetic and physiological process regulating the allocation of energy under given conditions of food availability and environmental stress.

It is assumed that anabolic processes are limited by oxygen inputs and thus are function of a surface-area, while catabolic processes would be proportional to the volume of the organism (Pennycuick, 1992;Damuth, 2001). However, catabolism and anabolism balances are also affected by stress through gene expression. Some findings show that fatty acid synthase, involved in the storage of excess energy as fat, is less expressed in polluted populations of the teleost fish Fundulus heteroclitus, suggesting that polluted populations may have limited energy stores (Oleksiak, 2008). Moreover, recent studies suggest that pollution affects the condition of eels from a metabolic point of view, given that key genes involved in respiratory activity, energy production and RNA expression are downregulated, possibly resulting in a low energetic status of the individuals (Pujolar et al., 2012). Other studies show that the differential expression of two cytochrome P450 aromatase forms in killifish (Fundulus heteroclitus) from polluted and unpolluted environments permits the killifish population to maintain the level of reproductive competence in the face of evidence of exposure to estrogenlike pollutants and endocrine disruption (Greytak et al., 2005).

Furthermore, exploring the genetic basis of alternate lagoonal and open-sea habitat use in western Mediterranean populations of the gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata), Chaoui et al. (2012) found that while anonymous markers globally indicated high levels of gene flow across geographic locations and habitats, non-neutral differentiation patterns correlating with habitat type were found at two candidate microsatellite loci located in the promoter region of the growth hormone and prolactin genes. They suggested that polymorphisms in the proximal promoter region could influence gene expression by modulating transcription factor binding, thus providing a potential explanatory link between genotype and growth phenotype in nature.

From an ecophysiological view, aerobic scope would, ultimately, determine the growth rates or reproductive success of individuals (Kooijiman, 1986;Pecquerie et al., 2009), which would result in a decrease in the chance of a population to survive and therefore have potential effects on the community and the ecosystem. The damage that a specific alteration of the environment may be causing to a population should be looked at in terms of the energy balance of its costs to individuals and their chances of reproduction. The energy gained by a species in the form of food is devoted primarily to the maintenance of its activity and basal metabolism, body growth and reproduction (Fig. 3). When environmental conditions are far from optimal, individuals are forced to devote more energy to physiological regulatory processes that permit their survival than to growth or reproduction. This naturally affects the size that a given individual can reach and its reproductive lifespan and fecundity. It will have consequences for the population size and the ability to stay in balance with other populations. However, these changes at population level are easily masked by natural population fluctuations, and, when they do become detectable, they may already be out of control or near the point of no return shown in Fig. 2. Here, the mechanisms regulating the energy budget in an individual could be crucial to detect alterations and stress in the homeostatic region of the figure. In fact, there is evidence that species could have some control over the process (Kooijiman and Lika, 2014a, b) and these mechanisms can operate even before the strict limits imposed by negative energy balances are reached. In sea urchins, Delorme and Sewell (2016) have shown that warm acclimation produces a decrease in feeding rate, coinciding with negative growth and gonad development, and a decrease in the respiration rate, suggesting metabolic depression, even though scope for growth calculations showed that the animals had energy available for somatic and gonad production.

The evaluation of food intake and locomotor activity after exposure to different sources of stress is common in physiological studies of fish. Frequently, such studies are also complemented by the measurement of other physiological parameters linked to metabolism, like blood glucose and plasma cortisol or oxygen consumption, and this information could be related to the effects on growth rates or fecundity of the individual. However, little is known about the threshold at which the energy costs involved in counteracting stress lead to a change in ecological strategy. Fig. 3. a) Metabolic scope for a fish depending on environmental stress (temperature). AMR is the active metabolic rate and SMR the standard metabolic rate. The difference between them determines the scope for growth and reproduction effort than sea bass individuals have available. b) Metabolic scope will be distributed to growth or reproduction in the framework of Dynamic Energy Budget theory and following energy allocation rules determining life strategies at individual, population and species level. The graph represents the von Bertalanffy Growth Function (where L t is the predicted mean length of the fish of a given population at age t; L = is their mean asymptotic length; K is growth rate factor, and t 0 is the theoretical age the fish would have at length zero). Some of the main variables characterizing life story are indicated on the graph.

div.head: Life story strategies
div.p: Environmental conditions, food and habitat availability, intra-and interspecific competition, and factors of mortality, both natural and human induced by fishing, determine the possibilities of survival and the development of target species populations. Species respond to these factors through a wide spectrum of life-history traits. At the extremes of the spectrum we find two main types of strategy, r and K (MacArthur and Wilson, 1967;Pianka, 1970;Margalef, 1974). r/K-selection theory refers to the population logistic growth model, where r is the rate of increase in the exponential population growth phase and K is the carrying capacity of the system. The r-strategy involves little care for offspring but species are characterized by high reproductive effort through early reproduction (i.e., early age of first maturity), small and numerous offspring with a large dispersive capability, short life-span and small adult body size. These characteristics may provide a selective advantage to a species in unstable or unpredictable environments since the ability to reproduce quickly is crucial in such situations, as in these environments there is little advantage in adaptations that would improve competition with other organisms in a given set of environmental conditions, because the environment itself is likely to be highly variable (Pianka, 1970;Heip, 1995).

At the other extreme, stable and predictable environments are dominated by K-strategy species. These species spend more energy on maintenance structures and adaptations to improve the ability to compete successfully for limited resources than on reproduction. For Fig. 4. Relationships between main variables characterizing life story in fishes estimated from FISHBASE data (Froese and Pauly 2008, http://www.fishbase.org/). Data include species from all kind of environments. n: number of cases (species); K somatic growth rate from von Bertalanffy's growth function; r max : intrinsic rate of population growth; length at maturity: average length at which fish of a given population mature for the first time; generation time: average age of parents at the time their young are born. this, they tend to be larger, longer living, less abundant, and show higher biomass/reproductive ratios than r-strategists. Other traits that are thought to be characteristic of K-selection include slow maturation and reproduction at a later age, with the production of fewer offspring, which, in turn, require extensive parental care.

Natural selection must act on physiological processes, leading to a combination of traits in an organism in a trade-off between devoting energetic resources to quantity (high numbers of offspring but little parental investment) and devoting energy to quality (fewer offspring but increased parental investment) (Pianka, 1970). Major changes in energy expenditure and allocation in the human lineage is considered the main driver of their unusual life history that combines high reproductive output with slow childhood growth and exceptional longevity, regarding other apes, leading finally to the evolution of a larger brain (Pontzer et al., 2016).

However, it should also be noted that life history data are not always easy to interpret in this manner and species cannot always be clearly classified, for example, into either r-or K-strategists (Stearns, 1977). In this context, research on physiological processes or energy allocation rules, sensu Sousa et al. (2008), that determine the selection between alternatives in the trade off may be crucial for anticipating environmental stress consequences on the populations and ecosystems.

Dynamic Energy Budget theory evolved on the basis of the similarities in growth patterns between organisms, as described by von Bertalanffy's growth curve and Kleiber's law on metabolic rate, suggesting that mechanisms that control the uptake and use of metabolites are common to all organisms (Sousa et al., 2008). However, regularities do not only affect individual behaviour but also extend to population dynamics and, therefore interspecific relationships and community structure in different ways (Huete-Ortega et al., 2012;Raerinne, 2013;Maino et al., 2014;Zhang and Feng, 2014). Kearney (2012) applied DEB models to the broad variation in growth rate, size and age at maturity, egg and clutch size and clutch frequency across the geographic range of North American lizard Sceloporus undulates, combining models of metabolism and behavioural thermoregulation, together with spatial climatic data, to predict geographic variation in growth rate, age at maturity and reproductive output. Development, growth and reproduction were predicted dynamically according to the κ-rule, whereby a fixed (throughout ontogeny) fraction κ of the energy/matter in the reserves flows to growth and to somatic maintenance, and the rest to increasing and maintaining the level of maturity and to reproduction once maturity is reached.

An analysis of the relationships between the different parameters constituting ecological traits, like the intrinsic rate of population growth, the individual growth rate, the age of first maturity (average age at which fish of a given population mature for the first time), the reproductive or life span, etc., show how strong these relationships are. Fig. 4 shows some of these relationships obtained from FISHBASE data (Froese and Pauly 2008, http://www.fishbase.org/) including up to 28,543 species of fishes from all kinds of environments.

The intrinsic rate of population growth (r max ) is considered one of the best indices of an organism's position on the r-K continuum (Pianka, 1970). The strong inverse correlation of body length with r max and generation time (defined as the average age of parents at the time their young are born) also suggests that the distribution of these parameters is a good measure to discriminate between ecological guilds with r and K strategies (Pianka, 1970). As Pianka (1970) showed, the intrinsic rate of population growth (r max ) is inversely related with generation time (T): r max = ln R 0 /T, where R is the net reproductive rate. Therefore, when r max data are plotted against generation time, a clear hyperbola is obtained, reflecting the reduction in r max associated with delayed reproduction (or increased generation time). The extremes of the hyperbola would represent the extremes of an r/K continuum range (Pianka, 1970).

There are also trade-offs involving other traits. For example, the trade-offs between fecundity and egg size have been studied by Elgar (1990) and Andersen et al. (2008). Recently, Plank et al. (2016) modelled evolutionarily stable strategies for fecundity and larval swimming speed of fish considering a trade-off between fecundity and larval survival probability, relating them to swimming speed, food encounter rate and metabolic cost. One of their conclusions is that in environments where there is little uncertainty in the food encounter rate, the stable strategy is a low-fecundity strategy with a swimming speed that minimises the mean time taken to reach reproductive maturity. Otherwise, when larval growth rates are unpredictable, a high-fecundity strategy is evolutionarily stable.

The strength of these relationships would, therefore, permit us to move from traits directly affected by environmental uncertainty and impacts or human induced mortality, like life span or life expectancy, to parameters directly related with physiological functioning and Energy budgets in the individual, like somatic growth rate (K in von Bertalanffy's growth curve), length at maturity (average length at which fish of a given population mature for the first time) or fecundity and then, to parameters affecting population growth and dynamics, like instantaneous population increase rate (r).

The key point is that in present DEB theory intraspecific differences in physiological rates derive solely from different values of state variables (length and stored energy density), while individuals of different species also have different parameter values (Nisbet et al., 2000). Therefore, DEB models are applied assuming that species show fixed or constant life strategy parameters, including maximum length (L max ), the fraction of utilized energy spent on maintenance and growth (κ) or the maximum fraction of the year during which the animal would reproduce if fed ad libitum (Nisbet et al., 2000;Kearney, 2012).

However, we would like to underline here that an interesting aspect of the trade-off between the different strategies is that it does not only operate at evolutive time scales, differentiating species, or at population level through genetic selection among a variety of genetic options. Although more research needs to be devoted to this topic, there is evidence that it occurs at all organization levels, including individuals, at least at key moments of their ontogeny, and to populations through phenotypic expression regulated, probably, by epigenetic mechanisms. Of course, in some cases, natural selection could determine restrictions to a wider plasticity, constraining the options spectrum of a given species, but there is sufficient evidence that life-history strategies show a high degree of plasticity in populations and in individuals depending on population density, resources availability and environmental conditions (Ota et al., 2012;Polacik et al., 2014). In fact, a key compound parameter in DEB models, like maximum length and the primary parameter length at puberty, are determined by life span, which depends on factors determining mortality (Fig. 4). In the case of reproductive period there is substantial evidence that water temperatures and photoperiod can lengthen the same. Sewell and Bergquist (1990) reported that the duration of the reproductive season and the timing of spawning of the temperate aspidochirote holothurian Stichopus mollis changed under El Niño conditions. The low sea water temperatures associated with the 1987 event in New Zealand increased the size of gonads, extended the duration of the reproductive season by four months and delayed spawning by 2-3 months. For fish, Kuo et al. (1974) showed that manipulation of photoperiod and temperature, alone or in conjunction with the use of exogenous hormones, can increase individual spawning frequency and prolong the spawning season throughout the year in mullet (Mugil cephalus).

An interesting case study for analysing physiological mechanisms regulating reproduction vs the allocation of resources for growth would be species that show sex allocation patterns as occur in many lineages of reef fishes. In a recent study in the parrotfish of Hawaii, De Martini and Howard (2016), in agreement with previous studies (Taylor, 2014;Taylor et al., 2014), not only showed differences in the size at maturity and sex changes among the five species considered, but also among populations of the same species depending on latitude, environment (temperature, habitat productivity), conspecific density and fishing pressure. This phenotypic plasticity in sex allocation was also observed in Serranus tortugarum, a small coral reef fish, by Hart et al. (2011). They performed experiments removing and marking fish from a highdensity site, transplanting them to a low-density site. After 4 months, the proportional male allocation of transplants mirrored that of residents at their new reef. The authors concluded that density can influence sexual selection and the social environment and lead to variation in growth and reproductive investment patterns and that phenotypic plasticity can facilitate reproductive strategies that maximize mating success in variable environments and lead to differences in sex allocation among populations.

A comparison between species settled in lagoons but typical of different environments (freshwater, marine, estuarine) and the migrant species that spend only some parts of their life cycles in estuaries and coastal lagoons to look for food or refuge, shows that each group of species modifies its strategy within the overall relationship (Pérez-Ruzafa et al., 2013) (Fig. 5). This study concludes that estuarine fish take advantage of productivity and environmental lagoon conditions to grow quickly and to reach the age of first maturity earlier, in order to have the largest possible lifespan and maximum fecundity; at the same time, they optimize the reproductive effort (low fecundity/size) investing energy to parental care of eggs including egg brooding. acceleration in metabolic rate, providing energy for larger brains and faster reproduction without sacrificing maintenance and longevity (Pérez-Ruzafa et al., 2013). This would be in agreement with Pontzer et al. (2016) claim that acceleration in metabolic rate, providing energy for larger brains and faster reproduction without sacrificing maintenance and longevity, was crucial in the evolution of human brain size and life history. The main conclusion of Pérez-Ruzafa et al. (2013) study is that these adaptations to variable and heterogeneous environments is not only a matter of species but also of assemblages and communities. Species play with a wide range of possibilities in a continuum, and any trade-off between biological traits is not always the same. Lagoonal selection would not necessarily act on all the biological traits of a species but only on some of them, improving the adaptation of local populations to the lagoon environment but upsetting the coherence of all biological traits in an r/K context. The authors agree with Stearns (1977) that r and K are not necessarily negatively correlated strategies, as most studies have assumed. Trade-offs are probably in practice relatively flexible, at least for some of the biological traits related with r/ K-selection. The heterogeneity in biological strategies and traits displayed by each species, in the framework of Dynamic Energy Budget theory and taking into account environmental stressors and food availability, allows the assemblage to cope with environmental stress and develop homeostatic mechanisms. Here, again, knowledge of the allocation rules that permit more than one trait to be improved is essential to link physiological process with ecological consequences.

The idea that ecological traits selection probably occurs at population level rather than at species level is reinforced by the observation that no one species inhabits exclusively estuarine environments. Species considered typically estuarine are freshwater or marine species that colonize estuaries and coastal lagoons (Barnes, 1989) and are common in only a few sites but are replaced by other species in other localities (Pérez-Ruzafa et al., 2011). In this way, lagoon environments shape and conform locally adapted populations, giving rise to euryhaline populations that reach their maximum development at an optimal site (Cognetti and Maltagliati, 2000).

A good example of life strategy plasticity is the human being, which show a wide margin of variation in strategies depending on the environment, social development and economy of the countries and regions (Leontief, 1979;Hofmann and Hohmeyer, 2013;Kreyenfeld, 2015). In the case of fish, fishing effects on fish growth, size structure, maximum age, age of first maturity, mortality and population fecundity have been widely reported (Kamukuru et al., 2005;Dunlop et al., 2007Dunlop et al., , 2015Dorval et al., 2015) and have promoted the use of Marine Protected Areas as the main tool for the management of fisheries (García-Charton and Pérez-Ruzafa, 1999;Halpern and Warner, 2003;García-Charton et al., 2008;Pérez-Ruzafa et al., 2008). In fact, differences in size are considered a simple, yet useful, indicator of fishing effects in Parrotfish (Valles and Oxenford, 2014), and these differences are related to reduced life span.

What is interesting is that the observed plasticity can be used by fish species to counteract negative effects on populations survival. Some modelling approaches show that, despite the emergence of pronounced differences in life histories produced by harvest-induced evolution, population growth rates did not differ appreciably because cumulative lifetime reproductive outputs were very similar among differing life histories (Kuparinen and Hutchings, 2012). As mentioned above, there is also a high degree of plasticity in fish populations and in individuals depending on latitude, population density, habitat characteristics or resources availability (Blanck and Lamouroux, 2007;Caselle et al., 2011;Ota et al., 2012;DeFaveri and Merila, 2013;Polacik et al., 2014).

Temperature is one of the clearest drivers of change of life story traits affecting growth rate, size, maturation and life span in marine fish over a short latitudinal gradient (Caselle et al., 2011;Sogard, 2011;Trip et al., 2014) and, recently, Riesch et al. (2015) reported rapid humaninduced divergence of life-history strategies between populations.

Pollutants may not only affect exposed individuals, for example the fecundity or the gestation time of females, but also their descendents. In a recent study, Cazan and Klerks (2015) showed that short-term exposure of gravid females to heavy metals can negatively affect variables of their offspring's life history and potentially influence population dynamics in a life-bearing fish species.

At organism level, the change in strategy clearly occurs during ontological development (Fig. 3b). There is a crucial moment (just before the age or size at first maturity) in which individuals change their investment from growth to reproduction. What is interesting is that, at least at species level, this moment is strongly affected by the maximum size/age reached by the species, that is, the expectations of life. Fig. 4 shows the relationship between age at maturity and maximum size or life span.

But, again, changes in this relationship do not operate at evolutionary time scales, but in a few generations as a consequence of changes, for example, in life expectations due to fishing pressure on the larger and older individuals in exploited populations. Again, human populations probably are a good example of how fecundity and age of first reproduction are postponed with increasing life expectations.

One interesting aspect of using these relationships or, even better, the physiological process involved, is that these changes do not occur a long time after environmental transformations, when it would be too late for the survival of the species, but early in the anticipation of future risks. Species and individuals must have some kind of receptors that allow them to anticipate the trophic and environmental conditions that will exist at the time of larval development, conditioning, within certain margins but in advance, their strategy. Some of these mechanisms have been described in fish like Arctic charr, which seems to possess timing mechanisms that include endogenous, circannual oscillator(s) entrainable by photoperiod probably linked to diel melatonin rhythms (Jørgensen and Johnsen, 2014).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Fish ecophysiology may represent a powerful tool for assessing the quality status of ecosystems and for anticipating the deterioration of ecosystems. The parameters defining somatic growth and fertility, life expectancy and the age of first reproduction of the species are closely related. At the same time, species and individuals respond to environmental pressures, resources availability and the effects of fishing by modifying such relationships probably in their life time and at population level, within certain margins, in the continuum of r vs K strategies. The factors and physiological processes that regulate the allocation of energy for growth or reproduction, within the framework of Energy Budget theory, are the key that links the physiological state of individuals with population dynamics and community structure (Fig. 6). Nisbet et al. (2000) already suggested the link between DEB model equations and life-history information, providing an opening to population dynamics, while Kearney (2012), based on the deviations in maximum size and the size of first maturity between model predictions and field data in some populations, suggested the possibility of testing DEB models when considering the plausibility of ontogenetic or spatial (local adaptation) changes in parameters: for example, that κ could be higher in one population than in others and hence an increased proportion of energy would flow to maturation and reproduction rather than growth and maintenance. In this contribution, we present evidence that individuals have certain margins to adapt their life strategies (size, fecundity) at certain times of their development and their life cycle. We believe that the study of the regulatory mechanisms of these processes, both at gene expression and physiological level, is essential for understanding and anticipating the response of species populations and their ability to adapt both to human pressures and the effects of climate change. This would allow a leap in scale from processes that explain action mechanisms to the consequences of the same for ecosystems and species distribution. Fig. 6. Conceptual model with the main interrelationships between life story variables and population dynamic and assemblage structure in response to main external drivers (food availability and environmental stressors including fishing). Blue box include external drivers; green arrows connect pairs of variables according expected direct or indirect cause effect relationships; (+) and (−) indicates the positive or negative relationship between connected variables; green boxes include the regression equations obtained from FISHBASE data () in this work; numbers in brackets relate these equations with the corresponding arrow in the diagram. Red boxes indicate the role of energy allocation rules in the link between physiological responses and ecological consequences.

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Plot of r max (intrinsic rate of population growth) against generation time for fish species inhabiting coastal lagoons in the Atlanto-Mediterranean region. Symbols and regression lines represent different ecological guilds (ES = estuarine species; MM = marine migrants; M = marine species; F = freshwater species; A = Anadromous species).
